page.title: 04Morley St. Peter's Church
page.content: Morley St. Peter's Church is on the south side of the village. It has a square tower, indicating that it was built in Norman times, and a graveyard. The graves are placed on the south side of the church because the shaded side represents a sign of the devil. Inside there is an altar, pulpit and lectern carved as an eagle. It has a stained glass window showing parables of the bible, and a font. About 30 people attend each week, but the services are alternated between St. Peter's and St. Botolph which is to the north west. It was built in 1240 and the respected John Graver Browne of Morley Hall is buried there in a vault under the nave. A number of rare wild flowers grow in the churchyard and therefore the grass is left to grow long SC21CS
